contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox bridge |image=William Jolly Bridge.jpg |bridge_name=William Jolly |official_name=William Jolly Bridge |locale=[[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] |carries=Motor vehicles, pedestrians and cyclists |crosses=[[Brisbane River]] |open=30 March 1932 |below= |design=Steel frame [[arch bridge]] |mainspan=three main arch of 72m each |length=500m |width= |coordinates={{coord|-27.46845|153.015491|type:landmark_region:AU|display=it}} }} The '''William Jolly Bridge''' is a vehicular and pedestrian bridge over the [[Brisbane River]] in [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. It is a steel frame [[arch bridge]] with an unusual concrete veneer and was opened to traffic on 30 March 1932 by Sir [[John Goodwin (governor)|John Goodwin]], the [[Governor of Queensland]]. When opened, during the worst year of the [[Great Depression]], the bridge was known simply as the Grey Street Bridge.<ref name="look">{{cite book |title=Looking up looking back at old Brisbane |last=Readshaw |first=Grahame |coauthors=Ronald Wood |year=1987 |publisher=Boolarong Publications |location=[[Bowen Hills, Queensland]] |isbn=0-86439-032-7 |page=52 }}</ref> It was renamed to the William Jolly Bridge on 5 July 1955 in memory of [[William Jolly]], the first [[Lord Mayor]] of Greater Brisbane.<ref name="look"/> ==Design== The aim of the bridge was to reduce traffic congestion on [[Victoria Bridge, Brisbane|Victoria Bridge]] during peak periods.<ref name="lhbris"/> It was designed by [[Harding Frew]], a local but prominent [[civil engineer]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Brisbane River: A pictorial history |last=Longhurst |first=Robert |coauthors=William Douglas |publisher=W.D. Incorporated Pty Ltd |location=Brisbane |isbn=0-646-34472-2 |page=26}}</ref> The style of the bridge's design is [[art deco]], which was popular at the time. Manuel R. Hornibrook's company built the bridge that consists of two piers that were built in the river and two pylons on the river banks, which support three graceful arches.<ref name="look"/> The rainbow arch type, as it was described, was claimed to be the first of its type in Australia.<ref name="lhbris"/> The concrete surface was treated to make it appear like "light-coloured [[Porphyry (geology)|porphyry]]".<ref name="lhbris">{{cite book |title=Living History of Brisbane |last=Hogan |first=Janet |year=1982 |publisher=Boolarong Publications |location=Spring Hill, Queensland |isbn=0-908175-41-8 |page=108 }}</ref> [[File:StateLibQld 1 92272 Construction of the William Jolly Bridge, Brisbane, ca. 1931.jpg|left|thumb|Construction of the William Jolly Bridge, Brisbane, ca. 1931.]] ==Traffic use== The William Jolly Bridge is shared by vehicular traffic, pedestrians and cyclists. It connects Grey Street in [[South Brisbane, Queensland|South Brisbane]] to Roma Street on the western edge of the [[Brisbane central business district]]. The bridge was conceived as a bypass for motor traffic between the southern suburbs and western suburbs of Brisbane to avoid increasing [[traffic congestion]] on the [[Victoria Bridge, Brisbane|Victoria Bridge]] and on downtown streets such as George Street. It was constructed with the intention of building [[tram]] lines over it and although the tracks were never installed, anchor points for tramway overhead were installed at the top of each arch. These overhead anchor points remain in situ. ===Congestion=== The bridge has two lanes for motor traffic in each direction, and a [[Sidewalk|footpath]] on each side of the bridge. By 2006, the [[Brisbane City Council]] reported that on a typical weekday, 42000 vehicles crossed the bridge and at peak times both ends of the bridge suffered from congestion. The [[Go Between Bridge]] is expected to relieve congestion on the William Jolly Bridge now that it has opened. ==Cultural references== The bridge was a location for the filming of ''[[Inspector Gadget 2]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,22929522-5012980,00.html |title=Casting director faces the camera |accessdate=2008-01-11 |work=[[The Courier Mail]] | first=Kellie | last=Alderman | date=15 December 2007}}</ref> ==See also== {{portal|Queensland}} *[[Bridges over the Brisbane River]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Structurae|id=s0004720|title=William Jolly Bridge}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2010}} {{Brisbane bridges navigation}} [[Category:Bridges in Brisbane]] [[Category:Bridges completed in 1932]] [[Category:Bridges over the Brisbane River]] [[Category:Arch bridges]] [[Category:Steel bridges]] [[Category:Road bridges in Australia]]
